Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project focuses on reducing the environmental footprint of conventional dyeing and finishing processes. This is enabled by the the significantly reduced level of contaminants, as well as the general sustainability, of nanocellulose as a raw material. Environmental and health concerns related to the effects of wastewater and consumption of water in the textile wet processing industry provide reasons for ongoing interest in the development of cleaner production methods. Nanocellulose-based technology uses cellulosic waste materials that would otherwise be discarded, thereby significantly decreasing the water usage and eliminating chemicals in the dyeing and finishing processes. This technology could help sustainability-focused companies to bring new products to the market and reduce their environmental impact.

This I-Corps project further develops functional nanocellulose hydrogels as a textile coating for cotton and blended fibers, yarns, and fabrics, with synthetic and indigo dyes. Nanocellulose coatings can be deposited on the surface of fibers, yarns, and fabrics made of synthetic and natural polymers for apparel, residential and contract furnishings fabrics, accessories, carpets, industrial, and smart textiles. Cellulose is an abundant natural materials that features sustainability, low environmental, health, and safety concerns, and provides biocompatibility. Nanocellulose is engineered, nanostructured cellulose, which is categorized as nanofibrillated cellulose and nanocrystalline cellulose depending on the production method and the overall size. Because of their low environmental impact, large surface area, and high reactivity, nanocellulose can be used as a coating and finishing alternative to the other chemically intensive materials and procedures.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Institution.Name: University of Georgia Research Foundation Inc
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF GEORGIA RESEARCH FOUNDATION, INC.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project's entailed five major goals.

1. To determine the target market for the technology in the textile, apparel, and home industry

2. To learn about the pain points of the target market (textile dyeing and finishing)

3. To test the hypotheses about the target market and to see if the need exists for this technology

4. To identify existing competitive technologies

5. Discovering critical segments of the business modal canvas, such as value proposition, channels, customer segments, key activities, key partners, cost structure, and revenue streams for the technology 

The target market was studied extensively during the I-Corps training program, and several potential manufacturing partners were identified, such as apparel brands, textile manufacturers, including dyers, weavers, and knitters.

Over the duration of the award, the process involved interviews with more than 125 people from over 50 companies in the textiles, apparel and home furnishings supply chain. These included representatives from the manufacturing of fibers, yarns, and textiles to dyeing and finishing, apparel garment manufacturing, wet and dry garment processing, apparel brands, and brick and mortar retail stores. The interviewees’ positions were comprised of multiple ranks from managers to CEO-level executives and included consultants, directors, product developers, research and development scientists and engineers, merchandisers, and designers. All interviews took place from October 2019 through January 2020 in the U.S.

The discovery process uncovered pain points such as water consumption and water waste treatment which continue to be an economic, social, and environmental issue for textile and apparel manufacturing, and ultimately the consumer.

The NSF I-Corps project's hypotheses determined that there is a growing environmental and health concern related to the harmful effects of toxic chemicals in textile wastewater and the massive consumption of water and energy in textile dyeing and wet processing. The results revealed that decreasing water consumption is a must-have in denim, piece, and garment-dyed manufacturing companies.

The combination of water, energy, and chemical (WEC) consumption and waste are the industry’s biggest challenges. These challenges require companies to develop and/or find new sustainable methods to decrease water consumption, energy costs, and toxic chemicals used in the dyeing of denim, yarns, and fabrics in textile manufacturing processes as well as in garment dyeing and garment wet and dry processing.

Through the I-Corps customer discovery, it was noted that many manufacturers are currently claiming a closed-loop system as a sustainable solution to water consumption and wastewater treatment. As sustainability transparency becomes a critical issue in textile and apparel manufacturing practices, this decades-long water recycling process has gained marketing attention recently but is not a new solution to water consumption and sustainability. Moreover, this does not address the use of toxic chemicals in the dyeing process. Current wastewater treatment methods are not fully effective for complete dye and chemical removal. The single process may not be adequate to decolorize the wastewater and remove the dye molecules completely. While some methods claim to be successful, the same treatment may not work for other types of dyes and chemicals. Despite the number of successful treatments using different physicochemical and biological methods, the high cost of the effluent treatments and the failure of these methods to entirely remove the toxic chemicals remain two major problems. It is essential to develop economically viable, environmentally friendly textile dyeing and finishing technologies that do not use massive amounts of water and do not produce toxic wastewater in addition to the more economically feasible wastewater treatment technologies.

While alternatives exist and continue to be introduced, most of these processes require expensive upgrades to existing equipment, increased labor and product development costs and still demand extensive chemical expense and water usage. This nanocellulose based coating and dyeing technology removes most of the toxic chemicals and replaces them with natural and eco-friendly materials leading to a significant reduction of economic and environmental costs in the manufacturing process. This technology offers cleaner production methods that address consumer demand for transparency and sustainability in the fashion and apparel industry by creating greener textile products compared to conventionally dyed and finished textiles.

 The big takeaways gained from the customer discovery were that sustainability initiatives such as reducing water, energy, and toxic chemicals are important for manufacturing, apparel brands, and the retail consumer. Both apparel brands and textile mills recognized that branding, public relations, and brand loyalty concerning sustainability issues are important to the consumer as well as to their companies and brand image. The lack of transparency in the textile supply chain regarding sustainability is the biggest problem. There is a consensus among global brands, such as Lee/ Kontoor, Levis, GAP, etc., to incorporate sustainable materials into their products by 2025.

The team intends to continue developing the technology with the goal of bringing the technology to commercialization. The next steps are to establish cost structure and prototypes with identified key industry partners.

 


Last Modified: 05/07/2021
Modified by: Raha Saremi
